hindu_succession_act_1956.title: Devolution of interest in coparcenary property
hindu_succession_act_1956.summary: Property of a Hindu male dying intestate shall devolve according to provisions of this Act. Coparcenary property devolves by survivorship among coparceners.
key_points: 2005 Amendment gave equal rights to daughters

hindu_succession_act_1956.title: General rules of succession in case of males
hindu_succession_act_1956.summary: Property of Hindu male dying intestate devolves first upon Class I heirs (widow, sons, daughters, mother) who take simultaneously and to exclusion of others. If no Class I heirs, then Class II heirs inherit.
key_points: Equal share to all Class I heirs
Widow gets same share as son/daughter
Daughters have equal rights since 2005 Amendment
Most frequently used section in partition suits
class_i_heirs: Son of predeceased son of predeceased son
Daughter of predeceased son of predeceased son
Widow of predeceased son of predeceased son

hindu_succession_act_1956.title: General rules of succession in case of female Hindus
hindu_succession_act_1956.summary: Property of Hindu female dying intestate devolves first upon sons/daughters and husband equally, then upon husband's heirs, then upon mother and father, then upon father's heirs, then upon mother's heirs.

transfer_of_property_act_1882.title: Sale - how made
transfer_of_property_act_1882.summary: Sale is transfer of ownership in exchange for price paid or promised. Immovable property worth Rs. 100+ must be registered.
key_points: Registration mandatory for property above Rs. 100

cheating_and_fraud.title: Cheating - Definition
cheating_and_fraud.summary: Whoever deceives any person fraudulently or dishonestly induces that person to deliver property or consent that any person shall retain property, or intentionally induces that person to do or omit to do anything which he would not do if not deceived, commits cheating.

cheating_and_fraud.title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
cheating_and_fraud.summary: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property or to make/alter/destroy valuable security shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years and shall also be liable to fine.
key_points: Most commonly charged section in fraud cases
Includes bank fraud, investment fraud, property fraud

cheating_and_fraud.title: Punishment for criminal breach of trust
cheating_and_fraud.summary: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment up to 3 years or fine or both.

forgery.title: Forgery - Definition
forgery.summary: Whoever makes false document or part of document with intent to cause damage/injury, or to support claim/title, or to cause any person to part with property, commits forgery.

forgery.title: Making a false document
forgery.summary: Person makes false document who dishonestly or fraudulently makes/signs/seals/executes document intending it to be believed that such document was made by authority of person who did not authorize it.

forgery.title: Punishment for forgery
forgery.summary: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both.

forgery.title: Forgery of valuable security, will, etc.
forgery.summary: Whoever forges document which purports to be valuable security, will, or authority to adopt son, or to make/transfer property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and shall also be liable to fine.
forgery.nature: Cognizable, non-bailable, triable by Magistrate of 1st class

forgery.title: Forgery for purpose of cheating
forgery.summary: Whoever commits forgery intending that forged document shall be used for purpose of cheating shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years and shall also be liable to fine.

forgery.title: Using as genuine a forged document
forgery.summary: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document which he knows to be forged shall be punished in same manner as if he had forged such document.
forgery.punishment: Same as punishment for forgery of that document (e.g., life/10 years for will)
forgery.nature: Cognizable if underlying forgery is cognizable

conspiracy.title: Definition of criminal conspiracy
conspiracy.summary: When two or more persons agree to do illegal act or legal act by illegal means, such agreement is criminal conspiracy. Provided no agreement except to commit offense shall amount to conspiracy unless some act besides agreement is done.
key_points: Illegal act or legal act by illegal means

conspiracy.title: Punishment for criminal conspiracy
conspiracy.summary: Whoever is party to criminal conspiracy shall be punished with same punishment as substantive offense. If no express provision, then imprisonment up to 6 months or fine or both.
conspiracy.punishment: Same as main offense OR 6 months/fine
key_points: Can be charged even if substantive offense not committed

conspiracy.title: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention
conspiracy.summary: When criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of common intention of all, each is liable as if done by him alone.

code_of_civil_procedure_1908.title: Rejection of plaint
code_of_civil_procedure_1908.summary: Plaint shall be rejected where it does not disclose cause of action, or is undervalued, or where suit is barred by law.
key_points: Court can reject plaint at threshold

code_of_civil_procedure_1908.title: Temporary injunctions
code_of_civil_procedure_1908.summary: Court may grant temporary injunction to restrain defendant where: (1) property in dispute, (2) right to property is seriously disputed, (3) defendant threatens to dispossess/cause injury to property. Court considers: (a) prima facie case, (b) balance of convenience, (c) irreparable injury.
key_points: Three conditions: prima facie case + balance of convenience + irreparable injury
code_of_civil_procedure_1908.when_granted: To preserve status quo and prevent irreparable harm during pendency of suit

specific_relief_act_1963.title: Declaratory decree
specific_relief_act_1963.summary: Any person entitled to any legal character, or to any right to property, may institute suit for declaration that he is so entitled. Court may make binding declaration without granting consequential relief.

specific_relief_act_1963.title: Perpetual injunction when granted
specific_relief_act_1963.summary: Perpetual injunction can be granted to prevent breach of obligation when compensation in money would not afford adequate relief.

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Primary evidence
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: Primary evidence means document itself produced for inspection of court. Where document in multiple parts, each part is primary evidence.

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Secondary evidence
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: Secondary evidence includes certified copies, copies from original by mechanical process, counterparts, oral accounts of contents. Admissible only when original is lost/destroyed or cannot be produced.

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Proof of execution of document required by law to be attested
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: If document is required by law to be attested (like will), it cannot be used in evidence until at least one attesting witness has been called to prove execution. Exception if all attesting witnesses deny execution.
key_points: Most important section for will disputes
indian_evidence_act_1872.application: Will propounder must prove: (1) Testator signed, (2) In sound mind, (3) Free consent, (4) Two witnesses attested

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Opinion of handwriting expert
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: When court has to form opinion as to person by whom document was written or signed, opinion of expert on handwriting is relevant.

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Proof of cession of territory
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: For proving cession of territory, court may look at maps, treaties, etc.

indian_evidence_act_1872.title: Court may presume existence of certain facts
indian_evidence_act_1872.summary: Court may presume that a person who has possession of stolen goods soon after theft is thief or receiver; that judicial acts have been regularly performed; that common course of business has been followed.

limitation: Article 59 (3 years from knowledge of fraud)
